headline.main: Report: Syrian Astronaut Flees to Turkey

headline.main: Neil Armstrong Dies at 82; Made 'Giant Leap' as First Man on the Moon

results.snippet: Neil Armstrong, who made the ''giant leap for mankind'' as the first human to set foot on the Moon, died on Saturday. He was 82.   His family said in a statement that the cause was ''complications resulting from cardiovascular procedures.'' He had...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD; John Schwartz contributed reporting. Susan C. Beachy contributed research

results.lead_paragraph: Neil Armstrong, who made the ''giant leap for mankind'' as the first human to set foot on the Moon, died on Saturday. He was 82. His family said in a statement that the cause was ''complications resulting from cardiovascular procedures.'' He had undergone heart bypass surgery this month in Cincinnati, near where he lived. His recovery had been going well, according to those who spoke with him after the surgery, and his death came as a surprise to many close to him, including his fellow Apollo astronauts.

headline.main: What's On Today

results.snippet: 9 P.M. (13) VIENNA PHILHARMONIC SUMMER NIGHT CONCERT 2012 Gustavo Dudamel conducts the orchestra, above, in the gardens of Schnbrunn Palace, a Unesco World Heritage Site. The program, taped on June 7 and presented here by ''Great Performances,'' is...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) VIENNA PHILHARMONIC SUMMER NIGHT CONCERT 2012 Gustavo Dudamel conducts the orchestra, above, in the gardens of Schnbrunn Palace, a Unesco World Heritage Site. The program, taped on June 7 and presented here by ''Great Performances,'' is centered on the theme ''Dances and Waves'' and features Tchaikovsky's Polonaise from ''Eugene Onegin,'' Borodin's ''Polovetsian Dances'' from ''Prince Igor,'' ''La Mer'' by Debussy, Richard Strauss's ''Salome's Dance'' from ''Salome,'' Ponchielle's ''Dance of the Hours'' from ''La Gioconda,'' Johann Strauss's ''Wiener Blut'' Waltz and Gimnez's Intermezzo from ''La Boda de Luis Alonso.'' 10:30 A.M. (CUNY) INVITATION TO WORLD LITERATURE David Damrosch, a professor of comparative literature at Harvard, introduces a range of writing in this new series, from Homer's ''Odyssey,'' ''The Bhagavad Gita'' and Voltaire's ''Candide'' to ''The Thousand and One Nights'' and Gabriel Garca Mrquez's ''One Hundred Years of Solitude.'' Featured readers include Philip Glass, Wole Soyinka, Kristin Chenoweth, Alan Cumming and Sandra Cisneros. ''The Epic of Gilgamesh,'' a Sumerian work dating from 2600 B.C., is the opening selection. (Repeated at 3:30 p.m.)

headline.main: Astronauts, Family Mourn Humble Hero Armstrong

results.snippet: Neil Armstrong was a humble hero who saw himself as a team player and never capitalized on his celebrity as the first man to walk on the moon, mourners said Friday outside a private service attended by fellow space pioneers, including his two...
results.lead_paragraph: Neil Armstrong was a humble hero who saw himself as a team player and never capitalized on his celebrity as the first man to walk on the moon, mourners said Friday outside a private service attended by fellow space pioneers, including his two crewmates on the historic Apollo 11 mission.
